description:
I run several Nextcloud instances, including one used by roughly 4,000 people. The desktop client has generally always been very reliable, in my opinion, and I've been personally using it since Owncloud, through the fork and continued on as a happy user.

I have run it on Gentoo, Arch, Kubuntu and even Windows. I have also found the Android client pretty stable as of around five years ago, on Samsung's finest.
summary: It just keeps on getting better

description:
(To admins: please set the license to "GNU GPL v2" instead of "unknown").

It saves my day, everyday. I have everything in sync: contacts, calendars events, files. This works on desktop, web, mobile, and command line scripts like "rclone". And everything is Open Source and Free software. Plus, option for encrypting files, a nd versioning, and online collaborative documents thanks to Collabora (the "LibreOffice" online) that supports also legacy Microsoft Office formats.

You can also create your own server, and it's a simple PHP/MariaDB application, super-easy to be installed, so you keep 100% data ownership and you make GDPR happy.

Thanks Nextcloud.

There really is no proper Nextcloud client for Fedora for some reason. The official AppImage, flatpak, and Fedora repo version are all broken. The UI is terrible and inconsistent. The tray icon works with the AppImage but the AppImage doesn't install to the system so it doesn't autostart and doesn't include an icon in the menu. I did not have this experience in Ubuntu or PopOS

The flatpak version of the desktop client do not work in the backgraund. I have to kill the app and to strtit again. The sync behaves every every time as it was am intial sync, rereading all the files again and again. After computer awakes from sleep mode, the app is offline and I have ti close it and restart it again.
It works on Debian 12 KDE Plasma without any issue.
The Flatpak seems to work well on Fedora 39 with Wayland and KDE Plasma 6.0.5
By default the system-tray popup is opened when you launch the application. This window cannot be moved or resized, and closes if it loses focus.
I love Nextcloud. I love the server, the integrations and all I can do with it. But this client simply does not work - it crashes instantly and as of now effectively hinders me from doing my work.
Title says everything.
summary: It does the job. No problem. I don't see why people put 1 star

description:
It's been a while since I used the sync client, and my god it has become quite the trainwreck. I've tried the DNF version, the Flatpak Version (from here) and the official AppImage from Nextcloud.com. They all show the same behavior:

- The UI Window has a form-factor that reminds me of a smartphone
- The UI WIndow doesn't have a handle of sorts or anything in fact that would allow me to resize or move it across the desktop
- But that's not an issue really, since the UI will just instantly disappear once it loses focus, never to be seen again
- There used to be a task-bar Icon for the sync client that showed the current status and allowed me to open the UI. That's plain gone. Once the UI window disappears, there really isn't a way to get it back (except for restarting the application)
- None of the (very few) buttons have any tooltip, and their Icons aren't all self explanatory

But the worst thing, really, is the fact that this **sync** client doesn't show the progress of **syncing** at all.

It hurts me to leave a review like this, but for me it's just not usable at all...
I was missing a desktop app to fully replace my dropbox usage with nextcloud. Now it is done.

It has room for improvement. I don't think the app itself looks great, and you need top icons extension from Gnome extensions to get the icon near the clock. It does what is supposed to do, but needs an interface refresh, and needs improvement in other areas.
I have been using it for some time now and use it to sync all my photos and documents cross platform and between multiple Linux systems, Windows, Android and it all works a treat. Great product.
I can't find a version that is usable. There is clearly no desire to have a functional client for Linux, which is odd.
Linux users are forgotten, again.
Funny, that worked on Plasma as supposed, but on phosh won't fit on screen :(

Seems to work fine in Debian 11 testing. Client could be a little prettier but functionality seems to be there.

I also tried the "online accounts" connection to Nextcloud. This mounts your Nextcloud as a remote share in the files application which I guess might be preferable for some people.
I use the Nextcloud client on other platforms just fine. This package installed via Fedora software utility starts and then crashes. Please package this properly and test.
Tested on Arch Linux, no issues so far. Perfect!

I've been using Nextcloud (client) on Windows, Ubuntu, Fedora KDE, and Fedora Gnome since 2017. It has always worked flawlessly. My server is running on a Raspberry Pi, crashed and re-installed once. I don't understand all the negative reviews except they must have configure things wrong or they have a bad network connection to their server.

Was driving me nuts always logging in as admin even though I setup other, normal user accounts on my server. The solution is to uninstall this client, then delete the ~/.config/Nextcloud, ~/.local/Nextcloud, and ~/.Nextcloud folders. Logout of your admin account in firefox, login with your Nextcloud user account, reboot (yes, absolutely needed!), re-install the nextcloud client and it should then connect to your normal user account. There needs to be an account disconnect/selection option in the menus. Good luck.

Client wise I have always used the direct download, but since my daily driver desktop is now Fedora Silverblue I have had to move to a Flatpack. This client lags a slight bit (time of writing I am on 3.6.1 - current release is 3.6.2), but it has been rock solid for the past 9 months or so. TL;DR; when Flatpak is your only client side option and you already know Nextcloud is for you then do not let the ratings here put you off.

L'intégration avec Gnome est un peu bizarre, mais c'est surtout un problème de Gnome. Pour plus de facilité à retrouver Nextcloud qui roule en arrière plan, vaut mieux installer l'extention de Gnome "AppIndicator and KStatusNotification" via l'app "Extension Manager".

Ce message ne concerne que le client, et ce qui me gène le plus pour le client c'est de ne pas pouvoir configurer facilement le démarrage automatique à l'ouverture de session. La case à cocher de l'application ne fonctionne pas, et d'après ce que j'ai vu c'est lié au fait que l'application d'origine a été encapsulée avec flatpak et qu'elle n'a donc pas le droit de configurer le démarrage automatique de la session... Ceci devrait être indiqué avant l'installation, et le menu avec la case à cocher devrait être mis à jour dans cette version du client nextcloud qui n'offre donc pas les mêmes possibilités que si on l'installe avec apt, ce que je vais faire.
